In the tripartite discussions last year the Government, theTUG and the OBI agreed on three objectives: to maintain a high rateof growth and to improve real incomes; to improve the position ofthe low paid and pensioners; and to moderate the rate of costand price inflation. On 6 November 1972 the Prime Ministerannounced that it had however not proved possible to reach agreement on the means of achieving these aims. The Government now had no alternative but to bring in statutory measures. There would be atemporary standstill during which the Government would work out proposals designed to secure the objectives.2. The Government now announce the next stage of their programme.This White Paper describes the policy to be pursued and the newlegislative framework which will supersede the Counter Inflation(Temporary Provisions) Act 1972. A draft Bill is published in acompanion White Paper (Cmnd. 5206).3. The Government commend these proposals to Parliament and tothe nation because they are essential if the higher rate of economic growth which is being achieved is to be sustained. Inflation isthe biggest single threat to our prosperity and to the improvementof our standard of living. By making our products less competitivein home and overseas markets and by impairing confidence in our ability to maintain growth, it endangers employment and investment.1 It also damages industrial relations and is socially unjust.k. Inflation is a world wide problem. Many countries have sharedin the recent sharp acceleration in the rates of price and payinflation. We must plan on the basis that the fight against inflation will continue for a long time to come. That is why theGovernment's proposals include some continuing machinery fortackling inflation. But these proposals are fully consistent withprogress towards voluntary arrangements.5. The Government acknowledge the cooperation and understandingshown by all sections of the community in the operation of the standstill. In the next stage the Government v/ill continue to rely on voluntary cooperation to the maximum extent possible.They believe that cooperative arrangements to check inflation arethe best way to proceed, and this White Paper explains how theGovernments proposals leave the way open for agreed voluntary arrangements in the future. But meanwhile responsibility forcombating inflation and safeguarding the higher rate of economic growth in the interests of the whole community rests with theGovernment.6. The draft Bill provides for the establishment of two newagencies: a Price Commission and a Pay Board. It also gives tothe Government and the agencies for a 3 year period powers toregulate prices, pay, dividends [and rentsj. It is intended thatall concerned with prices and pay should observe the relevantpolicies outlined in the next section of this White Paper, and in2---- ' a t? n -n m the Appendix. The Government will embody these policies in a codefor determining prices and pay, which will be laid before parliament in a statutory instrument and will, on approval, be applied by the agencies. Ministers will ensure that the agencies receive on a selective basis the necessary information about price and pay increases to enable them to apply the code to particular cases. They will thusplay a key role in implementing the policy within the code and willhave powers to enforce their decisions. The Bill will also give special powers to Ministers to ensure that prices reflect fairly theeffects of the replacement of purchase tax and selective employment tax by value added tax.7. To allow Parliament adequate time to consider the Bill and toavoid a gap between the expiry of the powers under the CounterInflation (Temporary Provisions) Act and the date when the powers under the new Bill become operative, the Government will ask parliament to approve an Order-in-Council for a 60 day extension ofthe Act. The legislative proposals are described more fully later in the White Paper. The next section sets out the policies.THE POLICIES8. The Government's policies are directed to attacking the rise inprices. A large part of price increases stems from domestic causes which we can influenee or control, especially pay and otherincreases. However some causes of price increases are outside thecontrol or influence of the United Kingdom. Ve are heavy imporbersof food and raw materials. The prices of these fluctuate on worldSECRET3 markets and in recent months many of them (eg meat, grain, wooland metals) have risen sharply. More broadly, the prices of nearly all our imports are affected by inflation in other countries andby rising demand as a result of higher living standards throughoutthe world. For example, there have been increases in the cost ofmany imported components and semi-manufactures for industry. Someprices will be affected gradually over the next few years by our obligations to the European Community. We can as a communityprotect some of our more vulnerable members against these increases.The Government are pledged to protect retirement pensioners by maintaining the purchasing power of their pensions and giving thema share in the nation's increasing prosperity when pensions arenext uprated. This White Paper contains proposals designed to give special help to the low paid. But increases in import costs are a charge on the living standards of all of us which, as a nation, wecannot avoid.9. Nevertheless the Government are determined to press home the attack on the domestic causes of rising prices. In working outthe policies to achieve this described in the next paragraphs, theGovernment have therefore had in mind three objectives: to steadyprices, to be fair, and to sustain a faster rate of economic growth. And in considering methods for implementing the policiesthey have looked for those which are as straightforward as possible,require the minimum of complex administration and allow flexibility in operation to meet differing circumstances. S E C E 23 TCONTROL OP PRICKS10. The Government intend to exercise firm control over prices.Manufacturers will not be permitted to increase their pricesexcept to the extent that they have to meet unavoidable cost increases. The extent to which these can be passed on in increased prices will be prescribed in the code of rules which the price commission applies. For this piirpose allowable costs will be strictly defined and there will, for example, be a reduction in them to ensure that the benefits of increased productivity are used to keep prices down. Pay increases which do not comply withthe policy will not be allowable. There will thus be no Questionof passing on all cost increases automatically as price increases.Manufacturers will also be required to reduce their prices if costreductions occur.Limit on profit margins11. These requirements will be backed by a limitation on profit margins on sales in the home market; net profit margins as a percentage of sales will not be allowed to exceed the average levelin the best two of the previous five years. If the limit isexceeded, price reductions will be enforced.Prior notification12. Large firms will be required to seek prior approval for price increases for manufactured goods. This requirement may also beapplied to other firms v/ith a substantial share of the market forcertain important products. Smaller firms not required to seekprior approval for price increases may be required to proviceregular information enabling the Price Commission to monitor tUeirprices effectively. Distributive Trades13. Distributors1 gross percentage margins will be held at theirpresent levels and this control will be backed by a limitation of profit margins comparable to that applied to manufacturers. Thiswill limit gross margins where the distributors purchase pricerises sharply. It is the Governments intention to ensure thatthe restraint exercised over manufacturers' prices is fullyreflected at the retail level; and that where unavoidable increasesoccur in the price of fresh foods and imported products, the resultant retail increases are no more than is strictly justified.1^-. Pay is the largest single element in those costs which are under our own control or influence and which are reflected inprices. There is no prospect of achieving a reduction in therate of price inflation unless increases in pay are brought wellbelow the levels reached immediately before the standstill whenincreases in both wage rates and earnings were running at 15-"16per cent above'a year before. Por some time to come these pre-standstill increases will continue to give rise to price increases*Bat over a period the rate of pay increases must be brought morenearly in line with the growth of output available to support them, so as to reduce price inflation progressively and improve the prospects of a sustained faster growth in real earnings.
